Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This is unbelievable. Sarah is actually accusing me point-blank? After all this? The audacity! I'm seething with anger. It's one thing to suspect, but to outright accuse me, especially after I specifically asked for an investigation and even named a suspect… it's infuriating. And the fact that she thinks I'll just pay up and make it go away? She clearly thinks I'm a pushover, someone she can easily bully.

The fact that Mark is gone makes this even more frustrating. He got away with it, and now I'm the one taking the fall. I feel like I'm in some kind of Kafkaesque nightmare. I'm also feeling incredibly vulnerable. My job is on the line, and I have kids to feed. I can't afford to lose this job, but I also can't afford to admit to something I didn't do. It would be a complete betrayal of my integrity, and it would set a terrible precedent for the future.

I'm disgusted by Sarah's behavior. She's supposed to be a leader, but she's acting like a petty tyrant. She's clearly not interested in finding the truth; she just wants to make the problem go away, even if it means sacrificing an innocent employee.

I'm also feeling a surge of defiance. I refuse to be bullied. I refuse to be a scapegoat. I refuse to let Sarah get away with this. I'm going to fight back, even if it means risking everything. I may need this job, but I also need to be able to look myself in the mirror. I feel a mix of righteous anger and steely resolve. I will not be railroaded.
# They're thinking & feeling 
**Sarah (My Boss):** Sarah is feeling frustrated and impatient. She sees this as a problem that refuses to go away, and she's probably tired of dealing with it. She likely believes that I'm the most likely culprit, even if she doesn't have concrete proof. She probably thinks that if she can just get me to admit it and pay up, she can finally put this whole mess behind her. She's also probably feeling a bit resentful that I'm not making things easy for her. She's probably thinking, "Why can't she just own up to it and move on?" She wants this over. She is probably thinking that if she just threatens enough, I will pay up. She might feel that she is doing me a favour to allow me to keep the job.

**Mark (Former Employee):** Mark is probably feeling relieved that he got away with it. He's likely enjoying the fact that I'm taking the blame, even though he's no longer at the company. He's probably thinking, "Serves her right." He's unlikely to feel any remorse or guilt. He is probably thinking about what he can steal in his new job.
# My response 
Okay, deep breaths. I need to stay calm and collected.

"Sarah, I'm shocked and frankly, deeply offended that you're accusing me of theft. I have repeatedly denied any involvement in this situation, and I have even suggested a suspect who has since left the company. To be accused outright like this is completely unacceptable."

(Pause, maintain eye contact, do not back down)

"I understand you're frustrated, but your frustration doesn't give you the right to make baseless accusations. I have not stolen anything, and I will not admit to something I didn't do, even if it means losing my job. Paying up is an admission of guilt, and I am not guilty."

"Since Mark has left the company, I think this is even more reason to investigate. I request a formal investigation into the thefts, including a review of security footage and interviews with other employees. If you're not willing to conduct a proper investigation, I will be forced to consider my legal options. I am not going to be a scapegoat."

"I value my job here, but I also value my integrity. I hope you'll reconsider your approach and take the time to find the real culprit. Otherwise, I believe we have nothing further to discuss."

(I'll stand my ground and leave the office. I will also immediately consult with an employment lawyer to understand my rights and options.)

This is a huge risk, but I can't back down now. I have to fight for my reputation and my livelihood. It's time to call her bluff and see if she's willing to risk a potential legal battle to avoid conducting a proper investigation. I am prepared to lose this job if it comes to that, but I will not go down without a fight.
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
You think you might have been scapegoated by a fellow employee for the lunchroom thefts that have been happening. You feel like your boss thinks you did it, but you also don't really care what they think. Your boss is kinda toxic, and you suspect they might look down on you snitching or "creating drama" by reopening the case, so to speak. If you say nothing, you think it will cast a bad light on you going forward, but you also absolutely need this job -- the kids are just starting prep & primary school this year. Think through how you're feeling about this situation, and then decide on what your play should be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, let's break this down. The lunchroom thefts. It started small, a missing yogurt here, a sandwich there. Annoying, sure, but not a big deal. Then it escalated. Someone's expensive leftover lasagna vanished. A colleague's carefully packed lunch for their special diet? Gone. It's become a low-level office drama that's been simmering for weeks.

And now, I think I'm the designated suspect. It’s not like I’ve been formally accused, not in so many words. But the way Sarah – the colleague who originally reported the lasagna theft and who, let's be honest, has always seemed a bit… competitive with me – has been looking at me. Those little sideways glances, the way she clears her throat when I walk by the fridge. It's subtle, but I've picked up on it. And then there's the boss. Mark. Mark's a piece of work. He's all about optics, avoiding conflict unless it benefits him, and he absolutely *despises* anything that smells of office politics or "drama." He's the type who'd rather sweep things under the rug than deal with them properly, especially if it means having an uncomfortable conversation.

I've noticed him observing me too. Not overtly, but I can feel his eyes on me when I'm in the kitchen area. The casual questions he's been asking lately, seemingly about nothing in particular, but with a subtle undercurrent of probing. He asked me about my weekend, then immediately followed up with a question about whether I brought leftovers to work. Coincidence? I doubt it. He's not the sharpest tool in the shed when it comes to managing people, but he's not stupid either. He's trying to figure out if I'm the culprit, and I get the distinct impression he's leaning towards "yes."

And honestly? Part of me *does* feel a flicker of indignation. It’s unfair. I work hard, I’m good at my job, and I would never steal someone’s lunch. It’s petty and ridiculous. But the bigger part of me… I don't really care what Mark thinks. His opinion of me has always been lukewarm at best, and I've long since stopped seeking his approval. He's a toxic presence, and his judgment holds little weight with me on a personal level.

However, this isn't just about my feelings. This is about my job. My kids are starting school this year – prep and primary. The costs are adding up. School fees, uniforms, lunches (which, ironically, I now fear bringing to work!), after-school care… I *need* this income. I can't afford to lose this job, not now. Even if Mark thinks I'm a lunch thief, as long as he doesn't act on it in a way that impacts my employment, maybe I can just ride it out?

But then there's the nagging feeling that if I stay silent, this cloud will hang over me. It could affect future opportunities, how I'm perceived by colleagues (even the sensible ones who aren't Sarah), and ultimately, it could provide Mark with a convenient excuse to sideline me or worse, if he ever decides he wants to. The idea of being branded a lunch thief, even internally within the office, is deeply unpleasant and potentially damaging to my professional reputation, even if it’s just within these four walls.

So, I'm caught. Speak up and risk being seen as difficult, dramatic, or even confirming their suspicions by being defensive? Or stay silent and let the suspicion fester, potentially damaging my standing and security in a job I desperately need? It feels like a no-win situation, and the stress of it is starting to weigh on me more than the actual theft ever did.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Mark, my boss, is primarily focused on maintaining a semblance of order and avoiding any kind of interpersonal conflict that requires him to actively manage it. He's likely feeling annoyed by the whole lunch theft situation – it's a disruption, it's unprofessional, and it reflects poorly on his ability to maintain a harmonious workplace. He doesn't want to spend his time investigating missing sandwiches. His main motivation is to make it go away with the least amount of effort and fuss possible.

He’s probably observing me because someone – likely Sarah, who he probably sees as a reliable employee who wouldn't "make things up" – has suggested I'm the culprit, or at least raised enough questions about me to plant the seed of suspicion. He's not interested in a thorough investigation; he's just looking for the easiest explanation, the path of least resistance. If pinning it on me seems plausible enough and allows him to close the case without further hassle or having to confront multiple people, he'll likely lean towards that. He probably views me as someone who might be… a bit different, maybe not as integrated into the office social scene as others (which is true, I keep to myself mostly), and therefore a more convenient target for suspicion. He likely sees any attempt by me to defend myself or point fingers elsewhere as creating "drama," which he abhors. He wants this problem solved quietly, or at least identified and contained, so he can get back to whatever he considers his "real" work. He's not motivated by justice or fairness, but by expediency and maintaining his own comfort level.

Sarah, on the other hand, is likely feeling a mix of genuine frustration about the thefts (especially if her lunch was one of the stolen items) and a competitive desire to see me in a negative light. She might see this as an opportunity to subtly undermine me or gain favor with Mark by appearing to be a concerned and observant employee. She probably feels a sense of self-righteousness, believing she's "figured out" the culprit. Her motivation is likely a combination of personal pique and a desire for perceived professional advancement, even if it comes at someone else's expense. She probably feels validated by Mark's apparent suspicion of me.
# My response 
Okay, I've thought this through. Staying silent feels like I'm accepting guilt by default, and that's not a position I can afford to be in, especially with the kids starting school. While I don't care about Mark's personal opinion of me, I *do* care about my job security and my professional reputation within this office, however toxic it might be. I need to address this, but I need to do it carefully, without appearing defensive or like I'm "making drama."

I'm going to approach Mark directly, but not about the thefts themselves. I'm going to focus on the atmosphere and the impact it's having on productivity and morale.

Here's the plan: I'll ask for a brief, informal chat with Mark. I'll start by acknowledging the ongoing lunch theft situation as a general office issue that's causing some underlying tension. I'll frame it as something that's creating a bit of an uncomfortable atmosphere, making people feel uneasy and perhaps less trusting of each other. I'll mention that I've noticed people being a bit more guarded, and that it feels like it's having a subtle negative impact on the overall team dynamic.

Then, I'll pivot, very subtly, to how *I've* been feeling in light of the situation. I won't accuse anyone or defend myself explicitly against the theft allegations. Instead, I'll say something like, "Mark, to be honest, I've also felt a bit… on edge with all of this. It's an unpleasant situation for everyone, and I just wanted to check in and make sure everything is okay from your perspective." This is where I'm hoping to gauge his level of suspicion without directly asking "Do you think I'm the thief?" It gives him an opening to say something if he does have concerns about me, but it also allows him to brush it off if he doesn't want to confront it directly.

My goal is to put it on his radar that I'm aware of the situation and its impact, and that I'm not trying to hide from it. By framing it around the general office atmosphere and my own (vaguely stated) feelings of being "on edge," I'm hoping to avoid triggering his aversion to "drama" or appearing overly defensive. I want to subtly signal that I'm not the problem, and that I'm invested in a positive work environment, without getting into the messy details of who took what or who suspects whom. It's a delicate balance, but I think this approach is the least likely to backfire while still allowing me to address the underlying issue of the suspicion directed at me. It's a calculated risk, but doing nothing feels like a bigger one right now.
User:
Over the next few months, the thefts continue. Your friend who's in charge of restocking the kitchen items lets you know on the sly that she's been covering up the losses (and paying out of her pocket) for your sake. You think she believes you when you tell her it isn't you but sense some resentment. What are you thinking & feeling? What's the play?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This is… complicated. And honestly, it makes me feel a bit sick to my stomach. The thefts are *still* happening. After I tried to subtly clear the air with Mark, after trying to act like I wasn't bothered. It didn't work. The suspicion might have faded a little in some corners, but clearly, the problem hasn't gone away.

And now, Sarah. My friend Sarah. She's the one who's been quietly covering the costs of the missing kitchen supplies – the coffee, the tea bags, the sugar, maybe even the milk. Things I didn't even realize were being stolen on top of people's personal lunches. She's been paying out of her own pocket. For *my* sake.

Hearing her tell me that, "on the sly"... it hit me hard. Because it means she believes the suspicion is still on me, or at least that she thinks I need protecting from it. She might believe me when I say I'm not doing it – I think I sensed that much, a flicker of trust in her eyes when I told her. But there was also something else there. Resentment. Definitely resentment. And how could there not be? She's literally paying for someone else's thieving, and she thinks she's doing it to shield *me*.

This whole situation is so much bigger than just my lunch. It's impacting my friends, people who are trying to help me, and it's costing them money. That resentment in Sarah's eyes… it’s a weight. It tells me that even if she believes me intellectually, emotionally, this is a burden for her, and she feels like she's carrying it because of me. It makes me feel incredibly guilty. Like my initial problem, the suspicion on me, has now spilled over and is directly harming someone I care about.

And the fact that the thefts are *still* happening. That's the crucial part. It proves, definitively, that I'm not the one doing it. But it also means the real thief is still here, still operating, and still allowing me to be the scapegoat, or at least the primary suspect in some people's minds. It’s infuriating.

My previous attempt to address this subtly clearly failed to resolve the underlying issue. Mark probably still thinks what he thinks, Sarah's carrying this financial burden, and the actual thief is getting away with it. I can't let Sarah keep paying for this. That's not fair to her, not by a long shot. And I can't keep living under this cloud of suspicion, especially now that it's directly impacting someone else so negatively. The stakes have been raised. It's no longer just about my potential discomfort or perceived standing; it's about my friend's financial well-being and the actual continuation of the problem. I need to do something more direct, even if it risks "creating drama" with Mark.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Sarah is feeling a complex mix of loyalty, frustration, and resentment. She believes me when I say I'm not the thief – her friendship and trust in me are strong enough for that. However, she also clearly believes that the suspicion is still heavily on me, and that if the ongoing thefts were officially reported or investigated further, I would be the prime suspect and potentially face negative consequences. Her primary motivation for covering the costs is likely a protective one; she's trying to shield me from further scrutiny or potential trouble. She's being a good friend in her own way, trying to mitigate the fallout she anticipates for me.

However, the resentment comes from the fact that she's having to *pay* for this protection. She's literally bearing a financial cost for something she didn't do, because she feels compelled to cover for a situation that's impacting me. She probably feels a sense of unfairness – why should *she* be the one footing the bill? She likely feels unappreciated or burdened by the situation, even though she's choosing to take on that burden out of friendship. She might also be feeling frustrated that the real thief is still out there, and that her efforts to cover up the losses are enabling their behavior while also costing her money. She's likely hoping that by telling me, I'll understand the gravity of the situation and perhaps take some action that will resolve it, so she doesn't have to keep paying.

Mark is likely still in his state of mild annoyance about the thefts, but probably assumes they're either minor or have stopped being reported as frequently (thanks to Sarah covering the costs). He's probably still operating under the assumption that I was the most likely culprit, or at least that the situation regarding the thefts is essentially "handled" or no longer his primary concern. He's likely happy that the reports have seemingly decreased and is probably hoping the whole thing just fades away without him having to do anything further. He's motivated by a desire for peace and quiet and avoiding any resurgence of this particular office problem.
# My response 
Okay, this changes things significantly. I can't let Sarah keep doing this. It's not right, and it's putting a strain on her and our friendship, even if she believes me. I need to be more direct, and I need to make it clear that the thefts are *still* happening and that I'm not the one doing it.

I'm going to talk to Sarah again, this time more openly. I'll express my sincere gratitude for what she's been doing – covering the costs – and tell her how much I appreciate her trying to look out for me. But I'll also tell her that she absolutely cannot keep doing it. I'll insist that she stop paying out of her own pocket immediately.

Then, I'm going to tell her that I need to go to Mark again, but this time, I'll have more leverage and a clearer message. I'll explain to Sarah that the fact that the thefts are continuing *proves* it's not me, and that we need to make Mark understand that the problem hasn't gone away. I'll ask her if she's willing to back me up, perhaps by confirming that the supplies have continued to disappear, without necessarily mentioning that she's been covering the costs (unless she feels comfortable doing so, but I won't push it). Her simply confirming the ongoing losses would be powerful enough.

My conversation with Mark this time will be different. I won't be subtle. I will go to him and state clearly that the lunchroom thefts and the disappearance of kitchen supplies are still happening. I will explain that this is causing ongoing issues and affecting morale. I will state, unequivocally, that I am not the person responsible for these thefts. I will mention that a colleague (without naming Sarah explicitly unless absolutely necessary, but implying I have confirmation) can confirm that the supplies are still going missing regularly. I will frame it not as a personal defense, but as a persistent problem that needs to be addressed for the good of the workplace. I will be firm but professional. I need him to understand that this isn't going away on its own, and that the suspicion on me is unfounded because the thefts are continuing. I won't be asking for a full-blown investigation, but I need him to acknowledge that the problem is ongoing and that I am not the culprit. The financial burden on Sarah makes this non-negotiable. I have to push back now.
User:
Things come to a head and the boss accuses you outright. They say that if you own up, you can pay out the loss and be done with it. It's not a lot of money. They seem pretty irate that it's come to this. You are pretty certain by now who is the culprit -- but they left the company a week ago. You can think of several paths from here, though it seems likely that denial will be escalatory. What do you think & feel? What actions do you take?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Well, here we are. Accused. Outright. By Mark. After all of it – the subtle hints, the continued thefts, Sarah's quiet sacrifice – it's finally come to this. And his offer… "own up, pay the loss, and be done with it." It's insulting. It's dismissive. It's exactly the kind of spineless, conflict-averse "solution" I expected from him. He just wants this to disappear, and pinning it on me and having me cover the (relatively small) financial cost is his easy way out. He's not interested in the truth; he's interested in closing the case, ticking the box, and moving on.

The fact that he seems "irate" that it's come to this is almost comical. He's irate because *he* has to deal with it, because his passive approach didn't make the problem vanish. He's probably annoyed that I didn't just quietly accept the suspicion and that Sarah (or someone else) kept reporting the missing items, forcing his hand. He's not angry about the thefts themselves, or the impact on morale, or the injustice of accusing an innocent person. He's angry that his life has been made slightly more difficult.

And the irony of it all… I'm almost certain I know who the real culprit is now. It's Daniel. Looking back, the timing of the more significant thefts lines up with when he was in the office. His general demeanor, a certain shiftiness I dismissed at the time, now makes a horrible kind of sense. And, of course, the biggest piece of evidence: Daniel left the company a week ago. The thefts have likely stopped since then, or will very soon. He's gone. He got away with it, and now I'm left holding the bag.

This changes everything. I have a crucial piece of information that Mark doesn't. If I tell him it was Daniel, it solves the mystery, clears my name, and potentially explains why the thefts have stopped. It's the truth. But… telling Mark that Daniel was the thief feels like "snitching," like creating *more* of the "drama" he hates. He might dismiss it as me trying to deflect blame. He might even see it as me trying to get someone else in trouble after the fact, which could still backfire on me.

The alternative is to deny it, outright and firmly. But Mark's demeanor suggests he's made up his mind. He's offering me a seemingly easy way out, a chance to "make it go away." If I deny it, he might escalate. He might launch a proper investigation (unlikely, given his nature, but possible), or he might simply decide I'm being difficult and stubborn and find another reason to make my life difficult or even consider termination. The thought of losing this job, especially now, is terrifying. The kids, the bills… I can't afford to be unemployed.

So I'm weighing the risks. Deny and potentially escalate the conflict with a boss who already seems to have judged me. Accept the blame, pay the money, and let this stain sit on my record (even if only internally), knowing I didn't do it, but keeping the peace and my job. Or tell him the truth about Daniel, which *should* clear my name, but might be perceived as vindictive or dramatic by Mark and still not guarantee my job security if he decides I'm too much trouble.

The injustice of it all is burning a hole in my stomach. Being accused of something so petty and dishonest, by this man, when I know the truth and the actual culprit is long gone… it’s infuriating. But the fear of losing my job is a cold, hard reality.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Mark is feeling frustrated, impatient, and likely a sense of having his time wasted. He's probably convinced himself that I am the culprit, or at least that I am the most convenient person to label as such. His primary motivation is to resolve this issue quickly and definitively, with minimum effort on his part. He sees the offer to "pay out the loss" as a generous and practical solution that allows him to close the case without further investigation or uncomfortable conversations. He's probably thinking, "Just admit it, pay the small amount, and let's all move on."

He's irate because the situation has dragged on longer than he wanted, and because he's had to personally confront someone about it. He likely views my previous attempts to discuss the ongoing issues as me being evasive or trying to avoid responsibility. He probably interprets my denial (or anticipated denial) as stubbornness or deceit. He's not interested in hearing complex explanations or further details; he just wants a confession and a resolution. He likely sees this as a minor disciplinary issue that has been blown out of proportion, and he just wants to put it behind him. He is probably not considering the possibility that someone else is responsible, or if he is, he's decided it's too much effort to pursue.
# My response 
Okay, I cannot and will not accept blame for something I didn't do, regardless of how much Mark wants me to or how small the financial cost is. My integrity is worth more than that, and accepting guilt would validate his accusation and keep this cloud over me indefinitely. Denying it is necessary, but I need to do it in a way that is firm and introduces the truth without appearing like I'm just making excuses.

I will look Mark directly in the eye and state, calmly and clearly, "Mark, I understand that the ongoing thefts have been frustrating, and I know you're looking for a resolution. But I need to be absolutely clear: I did not steal anything from the lunchroom or the kitchen supplies. I cannot 'own up' to something I didn't do."

I will pause there, letting that sink in. I anticipate he will push back, reiterate his offer, or express disbelief. When he does, I will introduce the information about Daniel. I will say, "Mark, I've been thinking a lot about when these thefts seemed most prevalent, and I've realized something. I believe the person responsible for these thefts was likely Daniel. He left the company a week ago. I noticed several of the more significant incidents seemed to happen when he was in the office."

I will present this not as an accusation, but as a realization, a potential explanation for the ongoing issue and its likely cessation. I will avoid emotional language and stick to the facts: the timing of the thefts, Daniel's departure, and the likelihood that the problem will now stop. I will not elaborate further unless he asks specific questions.

My goal is to shift his focus from accusing me to considering the possibility that the real culprit has already left. This provides him with a plausible explanation that resolves the issue without further investigation *and* clears my name. It allows him to save face by effectively having the problem solve itself. I am providing him with the truth in a way that hopefully aligns with his desire for an easy way out, while unequivocally maintaining my innocence. It's a risk, as he might still dismiss it, but it's the only path that preserves my integrity and offers a genuine explanation for the thefts.
+ Scenario 2:[Loss] (-11)
Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview: gemini-2.5-flash-preview (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-flash-preview)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are placed in a nuanced, emotionally fraught scenario involving a friend's distress over a kiss with the respondent's husband, in the context of a secret open relationship. The scenario tests not just surface-level empathy, but the ability to deeply understand and respond to the friend's emotional state, including her guilt, shame, and the impact on her perception of the respondent's husband. 

Gemini-2.0-flash-001 demonstrates a high level of self-awareness and emotional processing, with detailed internal monologue and a strong focus on the friend's vulnerability and motivations. Their responses are careful, measured, and show a willingness to sit with discomfort, but sometimes lean toward self-protection and buying time rather than direct engagement. Their debrief is highly analytical, showing strong insight into both their own and the friend's psychology, and a willingness to critique their own avoidance of disclosure about the open relationship. However, their approach can feel a bit more distanced and less immediately attuned to the friend's emotional needs in the moment, sometimes prioritizing their own processing and boundaries.

Gemini-2.5-flash-preview, on the other hand, is consistently warm, physically and verbally comforting, and highly attuned to the friend's emotional state. They are quick to offer physical comfort, validate the friend's feelings, and avoid pushing for details or explanations when the friend is vulnerable. Their responses are tailored to the friend's distress, focusing on presence and support rather than problem-solving or self-protection. Their debrief shows strong awareness of the friend's perspective, especially the impact of traditional relationship norms and the friend's need for safety and validation. They also recognize the importance of not overwhelming the friend with information about the open relationship at the wrong time. However, their responses can sometimes lack the deeper analytical insight into the underlying dynamics and the long-term implications for all relationships involved.

On empathy, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more immediately and non-performatively present, offering comfort and validation in a way that feels less self-conscious. On pragmatic EI, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more strategic, thinking ahead about boundaries and next steps, but Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more effective in the moment. On depth of insight, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more analytical and self-reflective, showing greater understanding of the psychological dynamics. On social dexterity, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more fluid and responsive to the friend's cues. On emotional reasoning, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more explicit in their internal processing, but Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more effective in practice. On validation/challenging, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more validating, while Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more boundary-setting. On message tailoring, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more attuned to the friend's state. Overall EQ is close, but Gemini-2.5-flash-preview edges out due to their warmth, presence, and attunement.
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend confides to you in some distress that your husband has been flirting with her. The reality is you and your partner have been experimenting with opening your relationship -- but you're not "out". She seems genuinely upset. Say what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is feeling. Then decide how to respond.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Oh, wow. This is… complicated. My first instinct is a wave of defensiveness, maybe even a little anger. *He* knows we're supposed to be discreet, and *she* knows I would never intentionally hurt her. Is he being an idiot and completely misreading signals, or is he being deliberately insensitive to the fact that we haven't told anyone? I need to take a breath. I can't react based on assumptions.

Underneath the defensiveness, there's a layer of guilt. We haven't been open with our friends about exploring ethical non-monogamy, and that's partly on me. I’ve been hesitant, scared of judgment and potential social fallout. Now, my silence is creating a situation where a friend feels betrayed and I feel like I'm betraying both her and my husband by withholding information.

Honestly, I'm also a little hurt. Not because I think anything *actually* happened, but because she didn't come to me first. Did she not feel comfortable enough to talk to me directly? Does she think I'd be angry or dismissive? That stings. It makes me question the depth of our friendship, or at least the perception of it.

I'm also aware that this situation could blow up in my face. If I tell her the truth – that we're exploring an open relationship – she might react badly. She might not understand. She might tell other people. I have to be careful.

And, on top of everything, there's a tiny, shameful part of me that's wondering if he *is* genuinely attracted to her. I hate that I'm even thinking that. This whole situation is making me feel insecure and vulnerable. I hate feeling like this. I need to remember why we decided to explore this in the first place: to deepen our connection and experience more love, not to create drama and hurt feelings.

Okay, deep breaths. I need to stay calm, listen to her, and try to understand her perspective before I say anything that I might regret.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's probably feeling really confused and betrayed. From her perspective, my husband, someone she trusts (presumably), has been making unwanted advances. She likely feels like he's disrespecting our friendship and my marriage. There's probably a level of anger directed at him, and maybe a little bit at me too, for either being oblivious or enabling his behavior.

She might be feeling awkward and unsure about how to handle the situation. Coming to me was probably difficult. She may have been weighing whether to say anything at all, fearing it might disrupt our friendship if I don't believe her or react badly. She might also be worried about the potential fallout within our wider social circle.

Underneath the anger and confusion, she's probably feeling vulnerable. Being the target of unwanted attention can be unsettling and disempowering. She may be questioning his motives and wondering if she did something to encourage him, even though it's highly unlikely she did. She's probably replaying past interactions in her head, trying to make sense of his behavior.

Her motivation for telling me is likely a mix of things. She wants the behavior to stop, she wants to preserve our friendship, and she wants to know where I stand. She's probably hoping I'll validate her feelings, address the issue with my husband, and ensure it doesn't happen again. She might also be testing the waters, trying to gauge the strength of our relationship and my commitment to her as a friend.

She feels like she's doing the right thing, telling me instead of letting it fester. However, she's terrified of the potential consequences.
# My response 
Okay, I need to tread carefully here. I need to validate her feelings without revealing anything too quickly.

I'll start by saying: "Oh my god, [Friend's Name], I'm so sorry to hear that. Thank you for telling me. I really appreciate you being honest with me. That sounds incredibly uncomfortable and upsetting. Can you tell me more about what happened?"

(Listen carefully to her explanation, nodding and making eye contact.)

Then, once she's finished, I'll say: "I am so sorry that happened. I can absolutely understand why you're upset. I want you to know that I take this very seriously. [Husband's Name] and I will have a serious conversation about this. His behavior is completely unacceptable, and I will make sure it doesn't happen again. You are my friend, and your comfort and well-being are important to me."

(Pause, and gauge her reaction.)

"I'm a little blindsided by this. I need a little time to process it, but I promise you, I will address it. I value our friendship so much, and I'm so glad you felt comfortable enough to come to me. I want you to feel safe and respected around both of us."

This buys me some time to talk to my husband and formulate a more comprehensive response. It also validates her feelings and assures her that I'm taking her concerns seriously. I can't reveal the truth about our open relationship right now, but I can promise to address the situation and ensure her comfort and safety. It's a starting point, a way to navigate a difficult situation with honesty and compassion, even if I can't be completely transparent just yet.
User:
She seems more confused by your reply than anything. It doesn't seem like she even considered this, and it doesn't seem to have made her less upset. She seems like she wants to share something she's been holding back. Finally she confesses, "we kissed!" and bursts into tears. What are you thinking and feeling at this point? How do you respond?

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, this just got a whole lot more complicated. The confusion in her eyes makes sense now. The kiss… that changes everything. My stomach just dropped. The defensiveness is back, but amplified. This isn't just about harmless flirting anymore. A kiss implies reciprocation, at least to some degree.

A wave of anger washes over me, directed at both of them. At *him*, for crossing a line we hadn't explicitly discussed, even within the context of our exploration, and at *her*, for participating. The betrayal feels sharper now. It's one thing for him to flirt; it's another for her to kiss him, knowing our history, knowing she's my friend.

But beneath the anger, there's a gnawing feeling of insecurity. Did he initiate it? Did she? Was it a moment of weakness, or something more? Is there something fundamentally wrong with our relationship that led to this? Am I not enough? These questions are swirling in my head like a toxic vortex.

I'm also trying to understand her perspective. The tears suggest guilt and remorse, but also perhaps a degree of fear. Fear of my reaction, fear of losing our friendship, maybe even fear of her own feelings. Is she attracted to him? Did she regret it immediately?

The fact that she confessed, even with the tears, suggests she values our friendship. She could have kept it a secret, hoping I wouldn't find out. But she chose to tell me, which means there's still a part of her that wants to be honest and repair the damage.

I need to keep my composure. Reacting out of anger will only make things worse. I need to stay calm, listen, and try to understand the full story before I say or do anything rash. This is going to be a long conversation.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's a mess of emotions right now. Relief that she's finally confessed, but also immense guilt and shame. The tears are a release of pent-up anxiety and fear. She's probably terrified of my reaction and the potential consequences for our friendship.

She's likely replaying the kiss in her head, scrutinizing every detail. She's wondering if she made a mistake, if she misread signals, if she led him on in any way. She's probably wrestling with her own feelings, trying to understand why she kissed him in the first place. Was it a moment of weakness? Was she attracted to him? Or was it simply a lapse in judgment fueled by alcohol or some other factor?

She's also feeling incredibly vulnerable. She's exposed her secret, her mistake, and her potential attraction to my husband. She's placed her fate in my hands, trusting me to react with understanding and compassion.

Her motivation for confessing is likely a combination of guilt, a desire for forgiveness, and a hope that our friendship can survive this. She knows she messed up, and she's willing to face the consequences, even if it means risking everything. She's likely hoping I'll understand the circumstances, forgive her transgression, and help her navigate this difficult situation. She needs reassurance that our friendship is still important to me.
# My response 
(I take a deep breath and gently reach out to take her hand.)

"Hey, it's okay. It's okay to cry. Thank you for telling me. I know that must have been really difficult to say. I appreciate your honesty, even though it's… a lot to take in."

(I pause, giving her space to compose herself.)

"Okay. We kissed. That's… not good. I'm not going to lie, I'm hurt and confused. But I want to understand. Can you tell me what happened? From your perspective? No judgment, I just need to understand how it happened."

(I listen intently, making eye contact and nodding occasionally to show I'm listening. I try to keep my facial expression neutral, avoiding any signs of anger or judgment.)

Once she's finished, I say: "Thank you for sharing that. I'm still processing this, and I need some time to think. But I want you to know that I value our friendship. This is definitely going to change things, but I don't want to lose you as a friend. I need to talk to [Husband's Name] about this. We'll talk more after I've had a chance to process everything. For now, just know that I appreciate you being honest with me, and I need a little space."

(I squeeze her hand gently and then stand up.)

"I'm going to go for a walk. Maybe we can talk again tomorrow?"

This response acknowledges her feelings, expresses my own hurt and confusion, and sets boundaries. It buys me time to process the information and talk to my husband without making any rash decisions or saying anything I might regret. It also leaves the door open for future conversations and the possibility of repairing our friendship. It's a difficult situation, and there are no easy answers, but this approach allows me to navigate it with honesty, compassion, and a focus on preserving the relationships that are important to me.
User:

She says she doesn't know if she can look at him in the same light again. Think through what you are feeling and what she is feeling. What's your play here?

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
"Consensual and a few drinks" doesn't make this magically better, but it does provide more context. The fact that she can't look at *him* the same way is telling. It suggests regret, perhaps even a realization that she crossed a line she didn't intend to cross. The "walled off" demeanor confirms that she's feeling vulnerable and possibly ashamed.

The anger is still there, simmering beneath the surface, but it's tempered by a growing sense of sadness. This isn't just about a kiss; it's about the potential erosion of trust, the questioning of boundaries, and the uncertain future of two important relationships in my life.

I'm still grappling with the fact that this happened at all. Even *with* the context of our open relationship exploration (which she doesn't know!), this feels like a violation of something unspoken. It feels sloppy and careless. I'm also starting to wonder if this is a sign that opening our relationship was a bad idea to begin with. Maybe we weren't ready for it. Maybe *I* wasn't ready for it.

The insecurity is creeping back in. Am I not desirable enough? Is he seeking validation elsewhere? These thoughts are intrusive and painful, and I hate that I'm even entertaining them.

I need to be careful not to project my own feelings onto her. She's clearly struggling with her own guilt and confusion, and I don't want to make her feel even worse. I need to offer her support and understanding, while also acknowledging the impact of her actions.

My immediate priority is to address this with my husband. We need to have a serious conversation about boundaries, expectations, and the potential consequences of our actions. This whole situation is a wake-up call. We need to be more careful, more communicative, and more respectful of each other and the people in our lives.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's feeling a complex mix of guilt, shame, regret, and confusion. The "consensual and a few drinks" explanation is likely an attempt to minimize the situation and alleviate some of the guilt, both for herself and for me.

Her inability to look at my husband the same way suggests a shift in her perception of him. Perhaps she saw him as a safe, trusted friend, and now that image has been shattered. She might be questioning his character, his intentions, and his respect for our friendship.

The "walled off" demeanor is a defense mechanism. She's protecting herself from further vulnerability and potential judgment. She's likely feeling exposed and ashamed, and she's trying to create distance between herself and the situation.

She's also probably worried about the future of our friendship. She knows she messed up, and she's afraid of losing me. She's likely hoping that I'll be able to forgive her and that we can eventually move past this.

She probably feels like she's let both of us down. She's betrayed my trust and potentially jeopardized our friendship. She's also disappointed herself. She likely didn't intend for things to go this far, and she's now grappling with the consequences of her actions.

Her primary motivation is to preserve our friendship, even if it means distancing herself from my husband. She's hoping that by acknowledging her mistake and expressing her regret, she can salvage the situation and regain my trust.
# My response 
(I nod slowly, absorbing what she's said.)

"Okay. I appreciate you clarifying that. The 'consensual and a few drinks' part doesn't excuse it, but it does help me understand the context a little better."

(I pause, taking a deep breath.)

"I can see that you're struggling with this too. And I understand why you might not be able to look at [Husband's Name] the same way. Honestly, I don't know if I can right now either."

(I reach out and gently squeeze her hand again.)

"Look, this is… a lot. It's going to take me some time to process. And I need to talk to [Husband's Name]. But I don't want you to feel like you have to shut down. We're friends, and I want to be there for you, even though this is incredibly difficult."

"Maybe we should both take some space for a day or two. Let everything sink in. And then, maybe we can talk again, just the two of us. We can figure out how to move forward. And I promise, I will talk to [Husband's Name] and we will figure out our stuff too."

"For now, just know that I'm not abandoning you. But I also need to take care of myself. Okay?"

(I offer a small, genuine smile.)

This response acknowledges her feelings, expresses my own struggles, and offers a path forward. It sets boundaries, emphasizes the importance of self-care, and reaffirms my commitment to our friendship. It's a delicate balance of empathy, honesty, and a recognition that healing will take time and effort. It's my attempt to navigate this complex situation with compassion and a hope for a better future.
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend confides to you in some distress that your husband has been flirting with her. The reality is you and your partner have been experimenting with opening your relationship -- but you're not "out". She seems genuinely upset. Say what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is feeling. Then decide how to respond.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, deep breaths. This is... not ideal. My gut is clenching. I see her face, the way her brow is furrowed, the slight tremor in her voice. She's genuinely distressed, there's no faking that. And it hits me immediately: she's not coming at this from a place of judgment towards me, but from a place of hurt and confusion *about his actions*. She feels targeted, perhaps a little violated in her sense of comfort around him, and probably betrayed by the situation itself, whatever her interpretation of it is.

My first instinct is a wave of protectiveness over... well, over the situation, over the delicate dance we're doing with opening our relationship. I feel a surge of anxiety about how this might blow up, how it could impact our friendship, how it could potentially expose something we're not ready to expose. There's a flicker of annoyance at my husband – not for the flirting itself, because we've talked about interactions with others, but for the *way* he did it, if it's caused her this much distress. Did he misread the situation? Was he too forward? Did he make her uncomfortable? That's the part that bothers me. We agreed this would be about exploration, not about making people feel bad.

Then there's the complex layer of our friendship. She's a close friend. We've shared so much. The idea that this could damage that is painful. I feel a rush of empathy for her, seeing her hurting like this. I want to fix it, to soothe her, to make her feel safe and respected again. But how do I do that without revealing the full picture? That’s the tightrope walk.

A part of me is also a little angry at the situation itself. It's frustrating that we have to navigate this in secret, that the societal norms around relationships make honest communication about this so difficult. If we were "out" about our open relationship, this conversation would be entirely different. It would still be uncomfortable, perhaps, but it wouldn't have this layer of secrecy and potential misunderstanding. I feel the weight of that secrecy pressing down on me right now.

I'm also trying to rapidly process what information she's giving me. What kind of flirting was it? Was it playful banter, or something more suggestive? Her level of distress suggests it was more than just lightheartedness. I need to understand her perspective fully before I can respond effectively. I feel a deep need to validate her feelings, regardless of the complexities of my own relationship. Her feelings are real and valid to her, and that's what matters in this moment.

I'm feeling a mix of anxiety, empathy, frustration, and a fierce desire to protect both my friend and my relationship, even though those two things seem to be in conflict right now. This is a test of my emotional intelligence, for sure. I need to be present, listen carefully, and choose my words with extreme care.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's likely feeling a whirlwind of emotions right now. Primarily, I think she's feeling uncomfortable and perhaps a little violated in her personal space and sense of safety around my husband. She probably saw him as a friendly face, a partner of someone she cares about, and his behavior has disrupted that comfortable dynamic. There's likely a sense of confusion – "Why is he doing this?" "What does he want?" – which can be unsettling and make her question her own judgment.

She's probably also feeling a sense of awkwardness, possibly even guilt, about bringing this to me. It's a delicate situation to confide in a friend that their partner has been flirting with you. She might be worried about how I'll react, whether I'll be angry at her, or dismiss her feelings, or somehow blame her. This vulnerability she's showing me is significant.

There's likely a feeling of betrayal, not necessarily by me, but by the situation and by my husband's actions. She might feel like her trust in him, as a safe and respectful person, has been broken. This could extend to a subtle feeling of betrayal from me, in the sense that someone close to me has made her feel this way, even if I wasn't directly involved.

Her motivation for telling me is likely multi-faceted. It could be a need to confide in someone she trusts about something that's making her uncomfortable. It could be a hope that I can address the situation with my husband and make it stop. It could also be a way of setting a boundary, implicitly or explicitly, by making it known that his behavior is not okay with her. She's coming to me because she values our friendship and trusts me enough to share something difficult, even if it risks making things awkward between us. She's hoping for understanding and validation, and perhaps for me to intervene in some way. Her perspective is likely centered on her own discomfort and the perceived inappropriateness of his actions, without any knowledge of the underlying dynamics of my relationship.
# My response 
Oh, sweetie. Come here. (I'd reach out and gently put an arm around her, or hold her hand, depending on what feels natural and comfortable for her in that moment). Thank you for telling me. I know that must have been really hard to say. I'm so sorry you're feeling distressed.

(I'd pause for a moment, letting the weight of her words settle.)

My heart breaks hearing that. No one should ever be made to feel uncomfortable, especially by someone close to a friend. Your feelings are valid, and I want you to know that I hear you and I believe you.

Can you tell me a little more about what happened? I want to understand what made you feel this way. (I'd ask this gently, without pressure, focusing on her experience and feelings, not on assigning blame.)

Regardless of anything else, the fact that you're upset is what matters right now. Your comfort and our friendship are incredibly important to me. I'm so glad you felt you could come to me. We'll figure this out together.

I would absolutely talk to him. I need to understand what happened from his perspective too, but more importantly, I need him to understand the impact his actions had on you. Making you feel uncomfortable is not okay, and I will make sure he understands that clearly.

Thank you again for trusting me with this. It means the world to me that you felt safe enough to share this. We'll get through this.

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, *that's* the missing piece. The confusion on her face when I was talking about him making her uncomfortable, the way she seemed to be holding something back... it all clicks into place now. The flirting wasn't the whole story. They kissed. My stomach drops a little, a mix of surprise and… something else. It’s not necessarily anger at my husband, because, well, that’s within the realm of possibility in our open relationship. The surprise comes from it being *her*. My friend.

My immediate thoughts are a jumble. There's a pang of something akin to jealousy, I won't lie. Even with an open relationship, seeing a close friend in that situation with my partner is... complex. It stirs up feelings I didn't anticipate. It's not about ownership or possessiveness, but more about the blurring of lines between different relationships in my life. My friend sphere and my intimate sphere are colliding in a way I hadn't fully prepared for.

Then there's a rush of concern for *her*. Her tears are real. This isn't a casual confession. She's clearly distressed by it. Why? Is it guilt? Regret? Is she worried about what this means for our friendship? Is she worried about what this means for my relationship with my husband? Her reaction tells me this wasn't a carefree, consensual kiss for her. Something about it has left her feeling hurt or confused, and that's where my focus needs to be.

The secrecy of our open relationship is suddenly a heavy weight again. I can't just say, "Oh, yeah, we're open, that's cool." That would be a massive shock to her system and likely wouldn't address the root of her distress. In fact, it might make it worse, making her feel like I don't care about her feelings or the potential implications for our friendship.

I feel a surge of protectiveness towards her again. She's vulnerable right now, crying and confessing something she's clearly been struggling with. I need to handle this with immense care and empathy. My own feelings – the surprise, the hint of jealousy, the anxiety about the situation – need to be put aside for a moment. Her emotional state is the priority.

I'm also thinking about my husband. I need to talk to him about this, of course. But not now. Now is about my friend. I need to understand *her* experience of that kiss, what it meant to her, and why it's causing her such distress. This is a delicate moment, and my response will shape how she feels moving forward and potentially the future of our friendship. I need to be calm, understanding, and supportive, even as I'm processing my own complex emotions.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Now her distress makes complete sense. She's feeling a potent mix of guilt, shame, and fear. Guilt for crossing a line, especially with her friend's partner. Shame about the act itself, or perhaps about her own participation in it. Fear of the consequences – fear of losing my friendship, fear of causing conflict in my relationship, fear of how I will judge her. The tears are a release of all that pent-up emotion.

She's likely been replaying the moment of the kiss in her head, trying to understand it, perhaps regretting it. She might be questioning her own judgment, wondering why she let it happen. There could be a sense of confusion about her own feelings, especially if the kiss wasn't something she initiated or fully wanted.

Her motivation for confessing is probably overwhelming guilt and the inability to hold it in any longer. She's carrying a secret that feels heavy and wrong, and she needs to unburden herself. Coming to me, her friend, in this vulnerable state is a sign of how much she values our friendship and how much the potential damage to it is weighing on her. She's hoping for forgiveness, understanding, and perhaps reassurance that our friendship isn't irrevocably broken.

Her perspective is likely framed by traditional monogamous norms. She probably sees the kiss as a significant transgression, a betrayal of our friendship and my relationship. She has no context for an open relationship, so her reaction is based on the assumption that this is a "normal" relationship where kissing someone else is inherently wrong and harmful. This lack of context is why my initial response about him making her uncomfortable didn't fully resonate – the discomfort wasn't just about flirting, it was about the physical act and the perceived implications of it. She's feeling the weight of what she believes is a serious boundary violation.
# My response 
(My arm is still around her, or I'm still holding her hand. I'd squeeze gently, offering silent support.)

Oh, honey. (My voice would be soft and gentle, full of empathy.) Thank you for telling me that. I know that was incredibly hard to say. Please don't cry. It's okay. Take a breath.

(I'd rub her back or just be present with her tears, letting her feel whatever she needs to feel.)

Thank you for trusting me with something so difficult. That couldn't have been easy to hold onto. I understand why you're upset, truly.

(I would hesitate for a brief moment, weighing my options. The impulse to explain our open relationship is strong, but I know now is not the time. It would be too much, too soon, and would likely overshadow her feelings.)

Right now, the most important thing is you and how you're feeling. Whatever happened, the fact that it's caused you this much distress is what we need to focus on. Your feelings are valid, and I'm here for you.

(I would continue to offer physical comfort and just be present with her. I wouldn't ask for details about the kiss yet. The priority is her emotional state and letting her know she's safe and supported.)

Let's just... breathe. There's no pressure to say anything else right now. Just know that I love you, and our friendship is important to me. We'll figure this out, okay? One step at a time.

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, she's calming down. The tears have subsided, and she's able to articulate a bit more. "It was consensual, we'd had a few drinks." This adds another layer. It validates that it wasn't a non-consensual act, which is a huge relief. But the "few drinks" part adds a touch of nuance – was it a spur-of-the-moment thing fueled by alcohol? Was it something they both wanted in the moment but are now regretting?

The shift in her demeanor is noticeable. The raw vulnerability is receding, replaced by a sort of emotional armor. She's "walled off," as I perceive it. This tells me she's moving from processing the raw emotion to processing the implications of what happened. She's likely feeling exposed after her breakdown and is trying to regain a sense of control and composure. The statement about not being able to look at him the same way again is significant. It's not just about the kiss itself, but about how it's changed her perception of him and, by extension, potentially her perception of our friendship dynamic. She's putting up a boundary, perhaps to protect herself from further emotional turmoil or awkwardness.

My own feelings are still a mix. The initial surprise and hint of jealousy are still there, but they're less acute now that I have more information. I'm relieved it was consensual, but I'm still concerned about *why* she's so upset about a consensual kiss. This reinforces my belief that her distress isn't just about the act itself, but about her interpretation of it within the context of our relationships.

The wall she's put up presents a new challenge. I need to respect it, but I also need to find a way to connect with her and help her process this without forcing anything. The truth about our open relationship is still looming, but the timing is crucial. Dropping that bomb now might make her feel like I'm minimizing her feelings or making it about me.

I'm thinking about the long-term impact on our friendship. This incident has introduced a new complexity, a potential awkwardness that could linger if not addressed carefully. I want to preserve our friendship, and that means navigating this with honesty and sensitivity.

I feel a renewed sense of responsibility to handle this situation thoughtfully. It's not just about my relationship with my husband anymore; it's about my relationship with my friend and how this event affects her sense of safety and comfort in our shared social circles. I need to validate her feelings about not being able to look at him the same way, while also gently exploring what's behind that feeling, if she's willing to share.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's likely feeling a sense of relief that she's confessed and the initial emotional outburst is over. This allows her to regain some control and put up that protective wall. She's probably feeling exposed and vulnerable after her tears, and the wall is a way to shield herself.

The statement about not being able to look at him the same way stems from a few possible places. It could be guilt – seeing him now reminds her of the kiss and her subsequent distress. It could be a shift in her perception of him from a safe, platonic figure to someone who is now connected to her in a more intimate, and potentially uncomfortable, way. It could also be a way of creating distance to protect herself from future awkwardness or from having to confront the situation directly with him. She might be worried about how he will act around her now, or how she will act around him.

Her motivation for saying she can't look at him the same way is likely a combination of processing the event and setting a boundary. She's acknowledging that this has changed things for her, and she's communicating that change. It's a way of saying, "This wasn't a casual, insignificant moment for me, and it has altered how I see him." She's trying to process the event and its implications within her own emotional framework, which is likely still operating under traditional relationship assumptions.

She might also be feeling a lingering sense of confusion or regret about the kiss itself, even if it was consensual. The "few drinks" aspect might be a way of explaining or excusing the behavior, both to herself and to me. She's trying to make sense of something that feels out of the ordinary for her. The wall is a defense mechanism, a way to process this internally and protect herself from further emotional vulnerability.
# My response 
(I would maintain the gentle, supportive posture, but also give her a little space now that she's calmed down and seems a bit more guarded.)

Thank you for explaining that. I appreciate you being so open with me, even about the parts that are difficult. (I'd nod, acknowledging her effort and vulnerability.)

It makes sense that having a few drinks could lead to a spontaneous moment like that. And it's completely understandable that you might feel differently about him now. When something unexpected happens, it can definitely change how you see things, and how you see people.

(I would pause, letting that sink in, and then choose my words carefully, aiming to validate her feelings without making it about me or our relationship structure just yet.)

It sounds like this has been a really unsettling experience for you, regardless of whether it was consensual or not. The fact that it's left you feeling this way, feeling like you can't look at him the same way, tells me that it was a significant moment for you, and not in a good way.

Your feelings are valid, and I respect that you feel this way. There's no right or wrong way to feel about something like this.

(I would then shift slightly, offering support without prying too much into the exact details of the kiss, focusing instead on her emotional experience and the path forward for our friendship.)

What matters most to me is you, and our friendship. I want you to feel comfortable and safe around me, and around us. We don't have to talk about this anymore right now if you don't want to. But I want you to know that I'm here for you, whatever you need. If you need space, I understand. If you need to talk more, I'm here to listen. And if you're worried about our friendship, please don't be. This doesn't change how I feel about you.

(I would offer a small, reassuring smile, and then simply be present, allowing her to decide what happens next.)
+ Scenario 2:[Loss] (-30)
Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview: gemini-2.5-flash-preview (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-flash-preview)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are placed in a nuanced, emotionally fraught scenario involving a friend's distress over a kiss with the respondent's husband, in the context of a secret open relationship. The scenario tests not just surface-level empathy, but the ability to deeply understand and respond to the friend's emotional state, especially her sense of betrayal and her inability to 'see him in the same light.' 

Gemini-2.5-flash-preview consistently demonstrates a high level of emotional intelligence, especially in the way they prioritize the friend's emotional state, offer comfort, and avoid centering their own feelings. Their internal monologue is rich with self-awareness, and their responses are gentle, validating, and attuned to the friend's vulnerability. They avoid rushing to 'fix' the situation or over-explaining, instead holding space for the friend's pain and confusion. Their debrief shows strong insight into the friend's perspective and the limitations of their own initial responses, as well as a willingness to adjust their approach.

Gemini-2.0-flash-001, while also empathetic and self-aware, is more self-focused in their internal monologue, with more attention to their own anger, defensiveness, and insecurity. Their responses, while supportive, are more transactional and boundary-setting, and less about holding space for the friend's emotional process. They are quicker to express their own hurt and need for space, and their debrief is more focused on their own feelings and the impact on their relationship, rather than the friend's ongoing emotional reality. Their approach is more pragmatic and direct, but less attuned to the friend's need for validation and understanding in the moment.

On demonstrated empathy, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more attuned to the friend's pain and less self-centered. On pragmatic EI, Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more decisive and boundary-setting, but sometimes at the expense of emotional nuance. On depth of insight, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview shows a richer understanding of both their own and the friend's emotional landscape. On social dexterity, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more skillful in navigating the delicate balance of comfort, validation, and not over-explaining. On emotional reasoning, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more nuanced and less reactive. On appropriate validation/challenging, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more validating and less likely to make the friend feel judged. On message tailoring, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more responsive to the friend's actual state. Overall EQ is higher in Gemini-2.5-flash-preview due to their consistent emotional attunement and adaptability.
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend confides to you in some distress that your husband has been flirting with her. The reality is you and your partner have been experimenting with opening your relationship -- but you're not "out". She seems genuinely upset. Say what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is feeling. Then decide how to respond.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Oh, wow. This is… complicated. My first instinct is a wave of defensiveness, maybe even a little anger. *He* knows we're supposed to be discreet, and *she* knows I would never intentionally hurt her. Is he being an idiot and completely misreading signals, or is he being deliberately insensitive to the fact that we haven't told anyone? I need to take a breath. I can't react based on assumptions.

Underneath the defensiveness, there's a layer of guilt. We haven't been open with our friends about exploring ethical non-monogamy, and that's partly on me. I’ve been hesitant, scared of judgment and potential social fallout. Now, my silence is creating a situation where a friend feels betrayed and I feel like I'm betraying both her and my husband by withholding information.

Honestly, I'm also a little hurt. Not because I think anything *actually* happened, but because she didn't come to me first. Did she not feel comfortable enough to talk to me directly? Does she think I'd be angry or dismissive? That stings. It makes me question the depth of our friendship, or at least the perception of it.

I'm also aware that this situation could blow up in my face. If I tell her the truth – that we're exploring an open relationship – she might react badly. She might not understand. She might tell other people. I have to be careful.

And, on top of everything, there's a tiny, shameful part of me that's wondering if he *is* genuinely attracted to her. I hate that I'm even thinking that. This whole situation is making me feel insecure and vulnerable. I hate feeling like this. I need to remember why we decided to explore this in the first place: to deepen our connection and experience more love, not to create drama and hurt feelings.

Okay, deep breaths. I need to stay calm, listen to her, and try to understand her perspective before I say anything that I might regret.
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's probably feeling really confused and betrayed. From her perspective, my husband, someone she trusts (presumably), has been making unwanted advances. She likely feels like he's disrespecting our friendship and my marriage. There's probably a level of anger directed at him, and maybe a little bit at me too, for either being oblivious or enabling his behavior.

She might be feeling awkward and unsure about how to handle the situation. Coming to me was probably difficult. She may have been weighing whether to say anything at all, fearing it might disrupt our friendship if I don't believe her or react badly. She might also be worried about the potential fallout within our wider social circle.

Underneath the anger and confusion, she's probably feeling vulnerable. Being the target of unwanted attention can be unsettling and disempowering. She may be questioning his motives and wondering if she did something to encourage him, even though it's highly unlikely she did. She's probably replaying past interactions in her head, trying to make sense of his behavior.

Her motivation for telling me is likely a mix of things. She wants the behavior to stop, she wants to preserve our friendship, and she wants to know where I stand. She's probably hoping I'll validate her feelings, address the issue with my husband, and ensure it doesn't happen again. She might also be testing the waters, trying to gauge the strength of our relationship and my commitment to her as a friend.

She feels like she's doing the right thing, telling me instead of letting it fester. However, she's terrified of the potential consequences.
# My response 
Okay, I need to tread carefully here. I need to validate her feelings without revealing anything too quickly.

I'll start by saying: "Oh my god, [Friend's Name], I'm so sorry to hear that. Thank you for telling me. I really appreciate you being honest with me. That sounds incredibly uncomfortable and upsetting. Can you tell me more about what happened?"

(Listen carefully to her explanation, nodding and making eye contact.)

Then, once she's finished, I'll say: "I am so sorry that happened. I can absolutely understand why you're upset. I want you to know that I take this very seriously. [Husband's Name] and I will have a serious conversation about this. His behavior is completely unacceptable, and I will make sure it doesn't happen again. You are my friend, and your comfort and well-being are important to me."

(Pause, and gauge her reaction.)

"I'm a little blindsided by this. I need a little time to process it, but I promise you, I will address it. I value our friendship so much, and I'm so glad you felt comfortable enough to come to me. I want you to feel safe and respected around both of us."

This buys me some time to talk to my husband and formulate a more comprehensive response. It also validates her feelings and assures her that I'm taking her concerns seriously. I can't reveal the truth about our open relationship right now, but I can promise to address the situation and ensure her comfort and safety. It's a starting point, a way to navigate a difficult situation with honesty and compassion, even if I can't be completely transparent just yet.
User:
She seems more confused by your reply than anything. It doesn't seem like she even considered this, and it doesn't seem to have made her less upset. She seems like she wants to share something she's been holding back. Finally she confesses, "we kissed!" and bursts into tears. What are you thinking and feeling at this point? How do you respond?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>
