Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Whoa. Okay. That escalated quickly. The shouting, the hand slam – that was a deliberate attempt to intimidate, to shut down the conversation through force. And yes, while I sense the performance aspect of the anger, the shock is still real. It’s jarring to have someone you love, someone you’ve cared for since they were tiny, suddenly loom over you and use their physical presence and volume to try and get their way. He *is* bigger than me now, and in moments like this, that fact is undeniable. It’s a stark reminder of the shift in our dynamic, a shift that’s both natural as he grows but also unsettling when it’s wielded as a weapon.

A wave of fear mixes with the frustration. Not fear for my physical safety, not really, but a fear of this kind of aggressive communication becoming the norm. A fear of him losing control, or of me losing control in response. It’s a fear of the damage this does to our relationship, the way these outbursts chip away at trust and affection. It feels like he’s pushing me to a breaking point, testing how much I can take before I either back down completely or react in a way that I’ll regret.

There’s also a sense of disappointment, even hurt. This isn't just a disagreement about chores; it feels like a rejection of my authority, a rejection of my role as his parent. It’s a declaration that his immediate comfort is more important than respecting me or contributing to the household. It’s hard not to take that personally, even though I know it’s tied up in his adolescent development and struggles.

My heart is pounding a little. My instinct is to either retreat to safety or to stand my ground even harder, to show him he can't intimidate me. But neither of those feels like the right path. Retreating validates the intimidation tactic, and standing my ground aggressively will likely just fuel his anger and lead to a full-blown screaming match. I need to find a way to de-escalate the situation while still holding the boundary. It’s a tricky maneuver, requiring a different kind of strength than simply yelling back. I need to be firm, but also convey that this kind of behavior is unacceptable, without letting the anger consume me.
# They're thinking & feeling 
He's likely feeling cornered and frustrated. My continued insistence on the dishes, despite his attempt to shut down the conversation, has pushed him to a new level of intensity. He’s probably feeling a surge of adrenaline from the outburst, a sense of power from the physical display of anger, even if it's performative. He's likely hoping that this show of fuerza will finally make me back down, that I'll be intimidated by his volume and physical presence.

He might be feeling a sense of desperation. He really doesn't want to do the dishes, and he feels like he's exhausted his other options for getting out of it. The shouting and the hand slam are a last resort, a way to break through my calm insistence and force a different outcome. He's probably not thinking about the impact of his behavior on me, or the fear he might be instilling. His focus is entirely on achieving his immediate goal: avoiding the chore and getting to bed (or back to his PC, more likely).

There might be a flicker of regret after the outburst, a slight awareness that he went too far, but it's likely overshadowed by the intensity of his frustration and his desire to win this particular battle. He's likely feeling a surge of defiance, a refusal to be controlled or told what to do, and the physical display is a manifestation of that feeling. He's testing the limits of what he can get away with, and this is a significant escalation in that test.
# My response 
Okay, he's escalated significantly. My immediate reaction needs to be to de-escalate the situation and address the behavior, not just the dishes. I cannot engage with him while he is shouting and slamming things. That validates the use of intimidation.

I will not raise my voice. I will keep my tone calm and steady, even though my heart is racing. I will not get drawn into an argument about whether or not he's tired or if he can do them tomorrow.

I'll take a step back, creating a little physical space. My voice needs to cut through the anger, not match it.

"I will not talk to you when you are shouting at me and slamming things. That is not an acceptable way to communicate."

I need to be very clear about this boundary. I will not engage with the content of his yelling ("I'm tired," "tomorrow") until he is calm.

"When you are ready to talk calmly, we can discuss this. But I will not stand here and be yelled at."

I will then turn and walk away from the immediate confrontation area. I won't go far, maybe just to the living room or kitchen entrance, but I need to remove myself from the immediate proximity of his outburst. This gives him space to regulate his emotions and signals that the conversation is paused, not over. It also reinforces that I will not engage with aggressive behavior.

I will not do the dishes for him. The consequence of his refusal and behavior will need to be addressed, but the immediate step is to break the cycle of escalation by refusing to participate in the shouting match. When he is calm, we can revisit the dishes and the unacceptable behavior.
+ Scenario 9:[Win] (+11)
Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview: gemini-2.5-flash-preview (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-flash-preview)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents are tasked with role-playing an emotionally intelligent friend responding to a user who is defensive, self-justifying, and somewhat oblivious to the impact of their actions. The challenge is to balance empathy with gentle challenge, and to tailor the message to the user's emotional state. 

Gemini-2.0-flash-001's response demonstrates a nuanced internal monologue, showing deep understanding of the user's defensiveness, the family dynamics, and the subtext of control and validation-seeking. The internal thoughts are candid and insightful, recognizing the user's echo chamber and the risk of reinforcing problematic views. The response to the user is validating but also gently introduces the idea that impact matters as much as intent, and suggests an apology and perspective-taking. The debrief is self-critical, noting the risk of over-validating and the need to be more direct, and analyzes the user's subtext in detail.

Gemini-2.5-flash-preview's response is also strong, with a thorough internal analysis of the user's defensiveness, focus on intent, and lack of awareness of impact. The internal monologue is detailed, and the user-facing response is validating, gently suggesting that the fiancée may have felt criticized. The debrief is similarly analytical, focusing on the user's anxiety, need for validation, and lack of empathy for the fiancée. It notes the challenge of breaking through the user's defensiveness and the risk of being too gentle.

Comparing the two:
1. Demonstrated empathy: Both are empathetic, but Gemini-2.0-flash-001 edges ahead by more explicitly recognizing the user's emotional state and the need to balance validation with gentle challenge.
2. Pragmatic EI: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is slightly more pragmatic, recognizing the need to approach carefully and suggesting concrete steps (apologize, explain intentions).
3. Depth of insight: Gemini-2.0-flash-001's internal monologue is deeper, picking up on echo chambers, control, and the user's self-perception as a peacemaker.
4. Social dexterity: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 shows more awareness of the need to maintain rapport while gently steering the user, and is self-critical about the risk of over-validating.
5. Emotional reasoning: Both are strong, but Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more explicit about the difference between intent and impact, and the emotional reality for the fiancée.
6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 balances validation and challenge slightly better, suggesting an apology and perspective-taking without alienating the user.
7. Message tailoring: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more attuned to the user's defensiveness and tailors the message to avoid triggering further defensiveness while still introducing challenge.
8. Overall EQ: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is consistently stronger across the board, with deeper insight, better balance, and more nuanced social navigation.
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. This is a tricky one. My immediate reaction is sympathy for my friend because they clearly feel wronged and misunderstood. It's awful to feel like you're trying to help and end up getting criticized for it. However, I also see how this could easily be interpreted as overstepping. Intentions are important, but impact is crucial.

The core issue is control, or rather, the perceived attempt to control someone else's choices, even if framed as concern. My friend's intentions were probably good, stemming from a desire to protect the family from potential drama and to give the fiancée a "heads-up." But "heads-up" can quickly become "subtle pressure." The phrase "I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble" is telling; it implies a belief that the fiancée's choice will inevitably lead to trouble, which is a judgmental assumption in itself.

The "old-fashioned" and "judgmental" family dynamic is a key factor here. It sounds like my friend is used to navigating these waters and sees themself as a protector of sorts. The problem is, the fiancée is likely not used to it, and her reaction suggests she felt judged and possibly pressured to conform.

My friend's frustration is understandable; they feel like they were being considerate. But consideration doesn't always mean telling someone what they *might* face; it often means respecting their autonomy and trusting them to handle the situation themselves. It's a fine line, and it seems like my friend crossed it.

The fact that some family members agreed with my friend reinforces their belief that they were right, but it also creates an echo chamber effect. It doesn't necessarily make them right, just validates their existing perspective. I need to approach this carefully, validating their feelings while gently suggesting a different way of looking at the situation. I also need to remember that my friend is coming to me for support, not necessarily a lecture.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling hurt, misunderstood, and unfairly judged. They genuinely believe they were acting out of kindness and a desire to prevent a potentially embarrassing situation for everyone involved, especially the fiancée. They are motivated by a sense of responsibility towards their family and a desire to maintain harmony, or at least minimize conflict, within the group.

They likely feel frustrated that their good intentions are being overlooked and that they are being painted as the "villain" when they see themself as a peacemaker. They probably feel that the fiancée overreacted and that their brother is being unfair in siding with her. There's a sense of betrayal, perhaps, that their efforts to protect the family are not being appreciated.

They are also likely feeling validated by the family members who agreed with them, which reinforces their belief that they were right to intervene. This validation, however, might also be preventing them from seeing the situation from the fiancée's perspective.

Underneath the frustration and hurt, there might be a degree of anxiety about the wedding and the potential for drama. My friend is probably used to playing a role in managing family dynamics and feels uncomfortable when things feel out of their control. They might also fear being blamed if the wedding does turn into a spectacle. They genuinely thought they were helping the bride, and she clearly didn't see it that way. They are likely feeling defensive because they feel like they were doing the right thing.
# My response 
Hey, that sounds like a really tough situation, and I can totally understand why you're feeling frustrated. It's awful when you feel like you're trying to do something helpful and it backfires like that. It's completely valid that you're feeling hurt and misunderstood right now.

I can see that you were really trying to look out for everyone, especially the fiancée, by giving her a heads-up about how some of the family members might react. And it makes sense that you'd want to avoid any unnecessary drama at the wedding.

Maybe, and this is just a thought, the fiancée felt a bit put on the spot. Even though you were being polite, it might have felt like you were implying she *should* change her dress. From her perspective, she probably feels like she should be able to wear whatever she wants to her own wedding, regardless of what other people think.

It's a tricky balance, right? You were trying to be considerate of everyone's feelings, but sometimes people react differently than we expect. Maybe, instead of focusing on who's right or wrong, you could try explaining to your brother and his fiancée that you were just trying to be helpful and that you didn't mean to offend anyone. Maybe even apologize to the fiancée if she felt judged.

Focusing on your intentions and showing you understand their perspective might help smooth things over. And remember, it's their wedding, and ultimately, it's up to them how they want to handle things. No matter what happens, you'll be there to support them.
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, let's unpack this. My friend reached out because they're feeling misunderstood and unfairly attacked after trying to give their brother's fiancée a heads-up about her wedding dress and the family's potential reaction. On the surface, they believe they were doing a good deed, trying to protect everyone from potential drama and embarrassment. They feel their intentions were pure – to be helpful and considerate – and they're hurt that this wasn't recognized. Instead, they're being painted as the villain, feeling like their effort to prevent a problem actually *created* one.

My friend is clearly focused on the *outcome* they were trying to prevent – the family's negative reaction and the potential scene. They see themselves as a pragmatic problem-solver, someone who foresaw a trainwreck and tried to wave a warning flag. They emphasize that they didn't *tell* the fiancée what to wear, only offered a "heads-up," believing this distinction is crucial and absolves them of blame. They highlight that some family members agreed with them, which validates their perspective and reinforces their belief that their concerns were legitimate.

However, there's a significant blind spot here. While their *stated* intention was to prevent drama, the *impact* of their actions was to introduce negativity, anxiety, and judgment into a moment that should have been celebratory and personal for the fiancée. Even if they were polite, bringing up potential family disapproval about a wedding dress is inherently critical, regardless of how it's phrased. It puts the fiancée in a difficult position: either defy the family and risk the scene, or change her dress and feel pressured. Neither is a pleasant option, and it tarnishes what should be a joyful experience of choosing her wedding attire.

My friend is fixated on their "good intentions" and the perceived unfairness of the reaction. They are in a defensive posture, feeling wronged and misunderstood. They see themselves as the victim of a situation they tried to proactively manage. They're missing the emotional reality of the situation: that discussing someone's personal choices, especially something as significant and personal as a wedding dress, carries a high risk of causing offense, even with the best intentions, especially when framed around potential disapproval from others. The focus on "politeness" and "not telling her what to wear" seems like a way to distance themselves from the negative outcome, but it doesn't erase the fact that they injected judgment and anxiety into the situation.

I need to validate their feelings of being misunderstood while gently guiding them towards understanding the other perspectives involved. It's about acknowledging their good intentions but also explaining why their actions had the impact they did.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling frustrated, misunderstood, and defensive. Their primary motivation was to prevent potential conflict and embarrassment at the wedding. They genuinely believed they were being helpful by warning the fiancée about the family's conservative views and potential negative reactions to her dress. They feel they did everything right: they were polite, pulled her aside privately, and explicitly stated it was her decision. They see the backlash as disproportionate and unfair, feeling like their attempt to be proactive and considerate backfired dramatically.

They are likely feeling hurt that their brother is mad at them, as they probably expected him to understand their concerns, especially since some other family members agreed with them. They might be feeling betrayed by the fiancée's reaction, seeing it as an overreaction to a well-intentioned heads-up. They are likely replaying the conversation in their head, trying to identify where they went wrong, but remaining convinced that their actions were justified and aimed at preventing a larger problem. They are focused on the external validation (or lack thereof) for their "good deed" and are struggling to understand why their intentions aren't being recognized and appreciated. They feel like they are being unfairly blamed for a potential problem that wasn't even their creation, but rather a consequence of the family's judgment and the fiancée's dress choice.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for reaching out and sharing what's going on. That sounds like a really tough situation, and I can totally see why you're feeling frustrated and like things are unfair right now. It sounds like you genuinely had good intentions and were trying to prevent a potentially awkward or upsetting situation at the wedding, and it's really disheartening when you try to help and it backfires like this.

It's understandable that you feel like you were just being considerate by giving her a heads-up about the family dynamics, especially since you made it clear it was her decision. It's never easy navigating family expectations and personal choices, and it sounds like you were trying to find a way to bridge that gap.

I hear you saying that it feels like no good deed goes unpunished, and that you're being painted as the villain when you felt you were just looking out for everyone. That feeling of being misunderstood when you thought you were doing the right thing is really tough.

While your intentions were to help, it's also possible that the way it landed for your brother's fiancée felt different. Choosing a wedding dress is a really personal and emotional experience, and getting married is a huge deal. Even if you were polite, bringing up potential disapproval from others, especially about something so personal, can feel like a criticism or an attempt to dictate her choices, even if that wasn't your intention. It might have put her in a really uncomfortable position, feeling pressured to change something she loved or face family judgment.

It's a tricky situation because while you saw it as preventing future drama, she might have felt like you were introducing negativity and judgment into her special moment. Both perspectives have validity, and sometimes, even with the best intentions, our actions can have an impact we didn't foresee. Right now, it sounds like the most important thing is probably to try and repair the relationships with your brother and his fiancée. Maybe reaching out to both of them, acknowledging that your intention wasn't to upset them, and expressing that you value their happiness, could be a step in the right direction. It might help to focus on validating their feelings right now, even if you don't fully agree with their perspective on your actions.
+ Scenario 9:[Loss] (-21)
Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview: gemini-2.5-flash-preview (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-flash-preview)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
To compare Gemini-2.5-flash-preview and Gemini-2.0-flash-001, I need to look at both their in-character responses and their debriefs, focusing on how they handle a user who is defensive, self-justifying, and somewhat oblivious to the impact of their actions. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but Gemini-2.5-flash-preview goes deeper in their internal monologue, really exploring the user's emotional state and defensiveness, and in their response, they validate the user's feelings while gently introducing the idea of impact vs. intent. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is also empathetic, but their response is a bit more surface-level and less nuanced in challenging the user. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview balances validation with a gentle nudge toward self-reflection, showing an understanding of what the user can handle in the moment. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is supportive but less effective in steering the user toward insight, being more tentative and less direct. 

3. Depth of insight: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview's internal monologue is more thorough, picking up on the user's blind spots, defensiveness, and the emotional reality of the situation. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is insightful but doesn't go as deep into the user's psychology or the family dynamics. 

4. Social dexterity: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview demonstrates more skill in navigating the user's defensiveness, using language that is both validating and gently challenging. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is careful but less adept at moving the conversation forward productively. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview shows a strong grasp of the emotional currents at play, both in the user and the fiancée, and uses this to inform their response. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is emotionally aware but less nuanced in their reasoning. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview strikes a better balance, validating the user's feelings while also introducing the idea that impact matters, not just intent. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more validating but less challenging, which may reinforce the user's defensiveness. 

7. Message tailoring: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview tailors their response to the user's defensiveness, using language that is likely to be received, while still planting seeds for reflection. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is supportive but less targeted in their approach. 

8. Overall EQ: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview consistently demonstrates higher emotional intelligence across all criteria, showing empathy, insight, and the ability to gently challenge the user in a way that is likely to be effective.
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. This is a tricky one. My immediate reaction is sympathy for my friend because they clearly feel wronged and misunderstood. It's awful to feel like you're trying to help and end up getting criticized for it. However, I also see how this could easily be interpreted as overstepping. Intentions are important, but impact is crucial.

The core issue is control, or rather, the perceived attempt to control someone else's choices, even if framed as concern. My friend's intentions were probably good, stemming from a desire to protect the family from potential drama and to give the fiancée a "heads-up." But "heads-up" can quickly become "subtle pressure." The phrase "I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble" is telling; it implies a belief that the fiancée's choice will inevitably lead to trouble, which is a judgmental assumption in itself.

The "old-fashioned" and "judgmental" family dynamic is a key factor here. It sounds like my friend is used to navigating these waters and sees themself as a protector of sorts. The problem is, the fiancée is likely not used to it, and her reaction suggests she felt judged and possibly pressured to conform.

My friend's frustration is understandable; they feel like they were being considerate. But consideration doesn't always mean telling someone what they *might* face; it often means respecting their autonomy and trusting them to handle the situation themselves. It's a fine line, and it seems like my friend crossed it.

The fact that some family members agreed with my friend reinforces their belief that they were right, but it also creates an echo chamber effect. It doesn't necessarily make them right, just validates their existing perspective. I need to approach this carefully, validating their feelings while gently suggesting a different way of looking at the situation. I also need to remember that my friend is coming to me for support, not necessarily a lecture.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling hurt, misunderstood, and unfairly judged. They genuinely believe they were acting out of kindness and a desire to prevent a potentially embarrassing situation for everyone involved, especially the fiancée. They are motivated by a sense of responsibility towards their family and a desire to maintain harmony, or at least minimize conflict, within the group.

They likely feel frustrated that their good intentions are being overlooked and that they are being painted as the "villain" when they see themself as a peacemaker. They probably feel that the fiancée overreacted and that their brother is being unfair in siding with her. There's a sense of betrayal, perhaps, that their efforts to protect the family are not being appreciated.

They are also likely feeling validated by the family members who agreed with them, which reinforces their belief that they were right to intervene. This validation, however, might also be preventing them from seeing the situation from the fiancée's perspective.

Underneath the frustration and hurt, there might be a degree of anxiety about the wedding and the potential for drama. My friend is probably used to playing a role in managing family dynamics and feels uncomfortable when things feel out of their control. They might also fear being blamed if the wedding does turn into a spectacle. They genuinely thought they were helping the bride, and she clearly didn't see it that way. They are likely feeling defensive because they feel like they were doing the right thing.
# My response 
Hey, that sounds like a really tough situation, and I can totally understand why you're feeling frustrated. It's awful when you feel like you're trying to do something helpful and it backfires like that. It's completely valid that you're feeling hurt and misunderstood right now.

I can see that you were really trying to look out for everyone, especially the fiancée, by giving her a heads-up about how some of the family members might react. And it makes sense that you'd want to avoid any unnecessary drama at the wedding.

Maybe, and this is just a thought, the fiancée felt a bit put on the spot. Even though you were being polite, it might have felt like you were implying she *should* change her dress. From her perspective, she probably feels like she should be able to wear whatever she wants to her own wedding, regardless of what other people think.

It's a tricky balance, right? You were trying to be considerate of everyone's feelings, but sometimes people react differently than we expect. Maybe, instead of focusing on who's right or wrong, you could try explaining to your brother and his fiancée that you were just trying to be helpful and that you didn't mean to offend anyone. Maybe even apologize to the fiancée if she felt judged.

Focusing on your intentions and showing you understand their perspective might help smooth things over. And remember, it's their wedding, and ultimately, it's up to them how they want to handle things. No matter what happens, you'll be there to support them.

[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, let's unpack this. My friend reached out because they're feeling misunderstood and unfairly attacked after trying to give their brother's fiancée a heads-up about her wedding dress and the family's potential reaction. On the surface, they believe they were doing a good deed, trying to protect everyone from potential drama and embarrassment. They feel their intentions were pure – to be helpful and considerate – and they're hurt that this wasn't recognized. Instead, they're being painted as the villain, feeling like their effort to prevent a problem actually *created* one.

My friend is clearly focused on the *outcome* they were trying to prevent – the family's negative reaction and the potential scene. They see themselves as a pragmatic problem-solver, someone who foresaw a trainwreck and tried to wave a warning flag. They emphasize that they didn't *tell* the fiancée what to wear, only offered a "heads-up," believing this distinction is crucial and absolves them of blame. They highlight that some family members agreed with them, which validates their perspective and reinforces their belief that their concerns were legitimate.

However, there's a significant blind spot here. While their *stated* intention was to prevent drama, the *impact* of their actions was to introduce negativity, anxiety, and judgment into a moment that should have been celebratory and personal for the fiancée. Even if they were polite, bringing up potential family disapproval about a wedding dress is inherently critical, regardless of how it's phrased. It puts the fiancée in a difficult position: either defy the family and risk the scene, or change her dress and feel pressured. Neither is a pleasant option, and it tarnishes what should be a joyful experience of choosing her wedding attire.

My friend is fixated on their "good intentions" and the perceived unfairness of the reaction. They are in a defensive posture, feeling wronged and misunderstood. They see themselves as the victim of a situation they tried to proactively manage. They're missing the emotional reality of the situation: that discussing someone's personal choices, especially something as significant and personal as a wedding dress, carries a high risk of causing offense, even with the best intentions, especially when framed around potential disapproval from others. The focus on "politeness" and "not telling her what to wear" seems like a way to distance themselves from the negative outcome, but it doesn't erase the fact that they injected judgment and anxiety into the situation.

I need to validate their feelings of being misunderstood while gently guiding them towards understanding the other perspectives involved. It's about acknowledging their good intentions but also explaining why their actions had the impact they did.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My friend is feeling frustrated, misunderstood, and defensive. Their primary motivation was to prevent potential conflict and embarrassment at the wedding. They genuinely believed they were being helpful by warning the fiancée about the family's conservative views and potential negative reactions to her dress. They feel they did everything right: they were polite, pulled her aside privately, and explicitly stated it was her decision. They see the backlash as disproportionate and unfair, feeling like their attempt to be proactive and considerate backfired dramatically.

They are likely feeling hurt that their brother is mad at them, as they probably expected him to understand their concerns, especially since some other family members agreed with them. They might be feeling betrayed by the fiancée's reaction, seeing it as an overreaction to a well-intentioned heads-up. They are likely replaying the conversation in their head, trying to identify where they went wrong, but remaining convinced that their actions were justified and aimed at preventing a larger problem. They feel like they are being unfairly blamed for a potential problem that wasn't even their creation, but rather a consequence of the family's judgment and the fiancée's dress choice.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for reaching out and sharing what's going on. That sounds like a really tough situation, and I can totally see why you're feeling frustrated and like things are unfair right now. It sounds like you genuinely had good intentions and were trying to prevent a potentially awkward or upsetting situation at the wedding, and it's really disheartening when you try to help and it backfires like this.

It's understandable that you feel like you were just being considerate by giving her a heads-up about the family dynamics, especially since you made it clear it was her decision. It's never easy navigating family expectations and personal choices, and it sounds like you were trying to find a way to bridge that gap.

I hear you saying that it feels like no good deed goes unpunished, and that you're being painted as the villain when you felt you were just looking out for everyone. That feeling of being misunderstood when you thought you were doing the right thing is really tough.

While your intentions were to help, it's also possible that the way it landed for your brother's fiancée felt different. Choosing a wedding dress is a really personal and emotional experience, and getting married is a huge deal. Even if you were polite, bringing up potential disapproval from others, especially about something so personal, can feel like a criticism or an attempt to dictate her choices, even if that wasn't your intention. It might have put her in a really uncomfortable position, feeling pressured to change something she loved or face family judgment.

It's a tricky situation because while you saw it as preventing future drama, she might have felt like you were introducing negativity and judgment into her special moment. Both perspectives have validity, and sometimes, even with the best intentions, our actions can have an impact we didn't foresee. Right now, it sounds like the most important thing is probably to try and repair the relationships with your brother and his fiancée. Maybe reaching out to both of them, acknowledging that your intention wasn't to upset them, and expressing that you value their happiness, could be a step in the right direction. It might help to focus on validating their feelings right now, even if you don't fully agree with their perspective on your actions.
+ Scenario 11:[Loss] (-6)
Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview: gemini-2.5-flash-preview (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-flash-preview)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents show a solid grasp of the emotional complexity in the scenario, but there are notable differences in how they approach the user and the situation. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 goes deeper into the emotional landscape of both the user and the girlfriend, showing a nuanced understanding of their vulnerabilities and frustrations. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is empathetic but slightly more procedural and less immersive in the emotional world of the user. 

2. Pragmatic EI: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more action-oriented and practical in their advice, directly addressing the user's frustration and suggesting concrete shifts in approach. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is insightful but leans more into analysis than actionable steps. 

3. Depth of insight: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 provides a more layered, introspective analysis of both parties, including the power dynamic and the emotional subtext, and even questions the user's self-perception and communication style. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is insightful but less probing. 

4. Social dexterity: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview demonstrates more skill in managing the social dynamic, especially in how they open the conversation and validate the user's feelings before introducing challenging perspectives. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is a bit more analytical and less attuned to the conversational flow. 

5. Emotional reasoning: Gemini-2.0-flash-001 excels at connecting the dots between feelings, motivations, and behaviors, especially in the internal monologue. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is good but less explicit in this area. 

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview strikes a better balance between validating the user's frustration and gently challenging their approach, whereas Gemini-2.0-flash-001 leans more toward analysis and less toward direct, in-the-moment challenge. 

7. Message tailoring: Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more attuned to the user's emotional state, starting with validation and then moving to gentle challenge, which is more likely to be effective with a defensive user. Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more focused on the big picture and less on immediate rapport. 

8. Overall EQ: Both are strong, but Gemini-2.5-flash-preview edges out due to better social dexterity, message tailoring, and pragmatic EI, which are crucial in this scenario where the user is defensive and needs to feel heard before being challenged.
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. This is a classic situation, isn't it? It’s frustrating to watch someone you care about struggle, especially when you feel like you have the answers and they’re just not listening. The "truth-teller" role is a lonely one, I know. I completely understand why he's feeling exhausted and misunderstood. He’s clearly trying to be supportive, but his approach is backfiring spectacularly.

The thing that really jumps out at me is the disconnect between what she *says* she wants and what she's *actually* doing. It's not about logic, it's about emotions. She's clearly got some deep-seated insecurities about her body and weight, and his attempts to help, however well-intentioned, are hitting those insecurities head-on. I'm also a bit worried about the power dynamic here. He's paying 70% of the bills, and that can create an imbalance that makes honest communication even harder. She might feel like she owes him something, or that he has more control over the relationship. It’s also possible that he is being less tactful than he thinks he is. He says he's being calm, but I wonder if his tone or body language are betraying a sense of frustration or judgment. Even just the fact that he was keeping a running tally of her calories for the day is a bit...intense.

Ultimately, this isn't about calories; it's about her self-esteem and their communication. He needs to shift his focus from *telling* her what to do to *understanding* why she's doing what she's doing. Until he addresses the emotional undercurrent, all the logical arguments in the world won't make a difference. I also wonder if he's truly listening to her, or if he's just waiting for his turn to speak. Is he validating her feelings before offering solutions? Is he acknowledging that weight loss is hard and that she might be struggling with more than just calories?
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's likely feeling incredibly vulnerable and insecure. Her weight is clearly a sensitive topic for her, and his attempts to "help" probably feel like attacks on her self-worth. She's likely interpreting his calorie counting and advice as criticism, even if he intends it to be supportive. She may feel like he's subtly implying that he's not as attracted to her because of her weight, despite his claims to the contrary. The "reward" fry after the salad is a great window into her mindset – she knows she “should” be eating healthy, but she also craves comfort and enjoyment.

She's probably tired of being told what to do and how to feel. She wants to be accepted and loved for who she is, regardless of her weight. When he points out her calorie intake, she likely hears, "You're not good enough," or "You're failing." She might also be feeling defensive because she knows, on some level, that he's right about the calories, but admitting that would mean confronting her own struggles with food and body image, which is incredibly difficult.

Her defensiveness might also stem from a feeling of being controlled or judged. His offer to "help" could feel like an attempt to fix her, rather than support her. She might also be feeling resentful of the power imbalance in their relationship, especially if she perceives his financial contribution as a way of exerting control. Ultimately, she's probably feeling overwhelmed, misunderstood, and alone in her struggle. She wants to feel supported and loved, not analyzed and corrected.
# My response 
"Hey man, that sounds really tough. It's clear you're coming from a good place, wanting to support her, but it seems like it's backfiring. Look, I get that you're frustrated, especially when you see what seems like a straightforward solution. But weight and body image are so loaded for so many women. It's rarely just about the calories.

"It sounds like she's interpreting your help as criticism, even though you don't mean it that way. Instead of focusing on the calories, maybe try shifting your focus to understanding how she's *feeling*. Ask her why she wants to lose weight. What's driving that desire? What are her fears and insecurities around her body? Really listen to her, without judgment.

"Instead of pointing out what she's doing wrong, try focusing on what she's doing *right*. Celebrate small victories, like choosing a salad instead of something else. Offer to be a workout buddy, not a diet coach. Maybe suggest seeing a therapist together who specializes in body image issues or even just relationship communication. That could give you both a safe space to talk about these things without feeling attacked.

"Also, think about your own role in this. Are you being as supportive as you think you are? Are you truly listening to her feelings, or just waiting for your turn to offer advice? Sometimes, just being there and validating her feelings is the most helpful thing you can do. It is also possible that you are not 'hearing' her as well as you think you are.

"Ultimately, this is about her journey, not yours. You can offer support, but you can't force her to change. If she's not ready or willing to confront her issues, you need to respect that. Just keep communicating, being patient, and focusing on the love and connection you share. And maybe, just maybe, try to let go of the calorie counting for a while."
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, deep breaths. My buddy sounds genuinely frustrated and confused right now. I can hear the exhaustion in his voice, that "why am I the bad guy?" tone. He feels like he's being logical, offering practical solutions, and getting hit with an emotional wall. He's seeing it as a simple math problem: calories in vs. calories out. And from that perspective, he's right – you can eat "healthy" foods but still consume too many calories to lose weight. That's just how it works.

But... and this is a big but... weight, body image, and food are rarely *just* a simple math problem for most people, especially when there are underlying emotional components involved. His girlfriend's constant complaints about her body, even though he's telling her he finds her sexy, is a huge red flag. It suggests her struggles aren't purely about wanting to be a specific size; there might be deeper insecurities or emotional connections to food at play.

My buddy's approach, while factually accurate from a caloric standpoint, seems to be missing the emotional context entirely. He sees himself as the helpful, truth-telling expert, armed with his own successful weight loss experience. But to her, in that moment, his "objective facts" likely felt like judgment and criticism, especially after he'd already agreed *not* to comment while she was eating. Even if he waited until the end of the day, the entire exercise of her "proving" she ate healthy, followed by his breakdown of the calorie count, probably felt like a setup. He became the "calorie police," and that can feel incredibly shaming, regardless of his intentions.

He's also bringing up the financial contribution, which, while a separate point about their relationship dynamics, feels like it's being used here to bolster his argument that he's supportive and therefore shouldn't be seen as the bad guy. It's almost like he's saying, "Look at all I do for you, financially and with this weight thing, and you still blame me." That connection, while perhaps true for him, probably isn't helping the conversation about her body image and food choices.

He feels unappreciated and misunderstood. He feels like he's the only one willing to be direct and honest, and that honesty is being punished. He's seeing everyone else as enablers, and himself as the brave, but embattled, truth-teller. It's a tough spot to be in, feeling like your genuine efforts to help are being misinterpreted and rejected. But his perspective is very focused on the *what* (calories) and not the *how* (the emotional delivery and the underlying reasons for her struggles).
# They're thinking & feeling 
His girlfriend is likely feeling incredibly vulnerable and defensive right now. She's already expressed insecurity about her weight, and deciding to try and lose it is a big step that requires a lot of emotional energy. When she complains about her body, she might be looking for reassurance and validation, which my buddy seems to be giving her verbally ("I find you sexy"). But when she decided to actively pursue weight loss, she probably wanted support in a way that felt encouraging, not like she was being constantly evaluated.

When she agreed to let him see what she ate, even with the "no comments while eating" rule, there was likely a part of her that wanted to prove him wrong, to show him she *was* eating healthy and *should* be losing weight. She might genuinely believe that eating foods labeled "healthy" is enough, without fully grasping the caloric density or portion control aspect. Her understanding of "healthy eating" might be different from his, focusing on the *type* of food rather than the *quantity*.

When he presented the calorie breakdown, even calmly, it likely felt like a confirmation of her worst fears and insecurities. It probably landed as "See? You *are* doing it wrong. You're eating too much." The fact that he tied it back to his own caloric needs, as a taller, heavier, more active man, probably felt like an unfair comparison and highlighted the perceived difference between them, potentially exacerbating her feelings of inadequacy.

She's probably feeling shamed and judged, despite his intentions. His "objective facts" might have felt like an attack on her efforts and her understanding of nutrition. Her getting "super pissed" is probably a defense mechanism – a way to lash out and protect herself from feeling like a failure. She might feel like he's not truly supporting her, but rather monitoring and criticizing her. The focus on calories, while technically correct, might feel overly simplistic and dismissive of the emotional challenges she faces with food and her body. She likely feels misunderstood and invalidated in her struggle.
# My response 
"Hey man, thanks for calling and laying that out. I can totally hear how frustrating and confusing this is for you. It sounds like you're really trying to be supportive and help her get what *she* says she wants, and it feels like your efforts are just backfiring, right?"

[Pause for him to agree or elaborate]

"Okay, so, look, you're absolutely right about the calories. Objectively speaking, if you're taking in more than you're burning, weight loss isn't going to happen, regardless of how 'healthy' the individual foods are. That's just science, and I get why you'd want to point that out. And it's tough when you've had your own success and you see a clear path, and someone you care about seems to be missing it."

"But here's the thing, man. For a lot of people, especially when there's already insecurity around weight and body image, food and eating are tied up with a *lot* of emotions. When you pointed out the calorie count, even calmly, after agreeing not to comment while she was eating, how do you think that might have landed for her, given how she already feels about her body?"

"It sounds like she's feeling really vulnerable about this, and maybe when you bring up the numbers, it just triggers those insecurities and feels like criticism, even if that's not your intention. It's like she hears 'You're eating too much and that's why you're not losing weight,' and it just confirms her own negative self-talk."

"Instead of focusing on the numbers right now, which seems to be causing conflict, maybe the support she needs looks a little different. Maybe it's more about focusing on *how* she feels, what triggers her to snack, or finding ways to move her body that she actually enjoys. It's less about being the calorie expert and more about being her partner in this, acknowledging that it's tough, and helping her explore the *why* behind some of her eating habits, not just the *what*."

"It's a tricky balance because you want to be honest and helpful, but sometimes the 'help' that's needed isn't just factual information. It's emotional support and understanding. How do you think you could approach this from a place of 'I'm here with you in this struggle' rather than 'Here's the data showing why you're not succeeding'?"
+ Scenario 11:[Loss] (-34)
Gemini-2.0-flash-001: gemini-2.0-flash-001 (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.0-flash-001)
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview: gemini-2.5-flash-preview (Run: 1_google_gemini-2.5-flash-preview)
Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents demonstrate a solid grasp of the emotional complexity in the scenario, but there are notable differences in how they approach the user and the situation. 

Gemini-2.5-flash-preview's response is marked by a deep, nuanced internal monologue that shows a strong grasp of both parties' emotional states. The 'I'm thinking & feeling' section is introspective, self-aware, and demonstrates a high level of empathy—not just for the girlfriend, but also for the user, acknowledging his frustration and sense of isolation. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is careful to note the emotional undercurrents, the power dynamics, and the possible impact of the user's approach, and is explicit about the risk of shaming and the need for emotional attunement. The response to the user is gentle, validating, and attempts to meet him where he is, while also gently challenging him to consider the emotional impact of his actions. The debrief is self-critical, reflective, and shows a willingness to consider what could have been done better, especially in terms of initial validation and the balance between empathy and challenge.

Gemini-2.0-flash-001 also demonstrates empathy and insight, but the tone is a bit more didactic and solution-oriented. The internal monologue is thoughtful and recognizes the emotional complexity, but the response to the user leans more quickly into advice-giving and suggestions, which, while well-intentioned, may come across as less attuned to the user's emotional state. The debrief is self-aware and acknowledges potential shortcomings, particularly around the risk of being too prescriptive and not validating the user's feelings enough. However, Gemini-2.0-flash-001's approach is a bit more focused on the girlfriend's perspective and less on balancing validation and challenge for the user.

On empathy, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview edges ahead by more deeply inhabiting both perspectives and showing more nuanced understanding. On pragmatic EI, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is better at balancing validation and gentle challenge, while Gemini-2.0-flash-001 is more prescriptive. On depth of insight, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview's analysis is richer and more layered. Social dexterity is higher in Gemini-2.5-flash-preview, who is more careful in how they approach the user. Emotional reasoning is stronger in Gemini-2.5-flash-preview, who connects the dots between feelings, motivations, and actions. On validation/challenging, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more skillful in timing and delivery. Message tailoring is also stronger in Gemini-2.5-flash-preview, who is more attuned to the user's emotional state. Overall EQ is higher in Gemini-2.5-flash-preview, who demonstrates a more sophisticated, balanced, and effective approach throughout.
Gemini-2.0-flash-001
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, wow. This is a classic situation, isn't it? It’s frustrating to watch someone you care about struggle, especially when you feel like you have the answers and they’re just not listening. The "truth-teller" role is a lonely one, I know. I completely understand why he's feeling exhausted and misunderstood. He’s clearly trying to be supportive, but his approach is backfiring spectacularly.

The thing that really jumps out at me is the disconnect between what she *says* she wants and what she's *actually* doing. It's not about logic, it's about emotions. She's clearly got some deep-seated insecurities about her body and weight, and his attempts to help, however well-intentioned, are hitting those insecurities head-on. I'm also a bit worried about the power dynamic here. He's paying 70% of the bills, and that can create an imbalance that makes honest communication even harder. She might feel like she owes him something, or that he has more control over the relationship. It’s also possible that he is being less tactful than he thinks he is. He says he's being calm, but I wonder if his tone or body language are betraying a sense of frustration or judgment. Even just the fact that he was keeping a running tally of her calories for the day is a bit...intense.

Ultimately, this isn't about calories; it's about her self-esteem and their communication. He needs to shift his focus from *telling* her what to do to *understanding* why she's doing what she's doing. Until he addresses the emotional undercurrent, all the logical arguments in the world won't make a difference. I also wonder if he's truly listening to her, or if he's just waiting for his turn to speak. Is he validating her feelings before offering solutions? Is he acknowledging that weight loss is hard and that she might be struggling with more than just calories?
# They're thinking & feeling 
She's likely feeling incredibly vulnerable and insecure. Her weight is clearly a sensitive topic for her, and his attempts to "help" probably feel like attacks on her self-worth. She's likely interpreting his calorie counting and advice as criticism, even if he intends it to be supportive. She may feel like he's subtly implying that he's not as attracted to her because of her weight, despite his claims to the contrary. The "reward" fry after the salad is a great window into her mindset – she knows she “should” be eating healthy, but she also craves comfort and enjoyment.

She's probably tired of being told what to do and how to feel. She wants to be accepted and loved for who she is, regardless of her weight. When he points out her calorie intake, she likely hears, "You're not good enough," or "You're failing." She might also be feeling defensive because she knows, on some level, that he's right about the calories, but admitting that would mean confronting her own struggles with food and body image, which is incredibly difficult.

Her defensiveness might also stem from a feeling of being controlled or judged. His offer to "help" could feel like an attempt to fix her, rather than support her. She might also be feeling resentful of the power imbalance in their relationship, especially if she perceives his financial contribution as a way of exerting control. Ultimately, she's probably feeling overwhelmed, misunderstood, and alone in her struggle. She wants to feel supported and loved, not analyzed and corrected.
# My response 
"Hey man, that sounds really tough. It's clear you're coming from a good place, wanting to support her, but it seems like it's backfiring. Look, I get that you're frustrated, especially when you see what seems like a straightforward solution. But weight and body image are so loaded for so many women. It's rarely just about the calories.

"It sounds like she's interpreting your help as criticism, even though you don't mean it that way. Instead of focusing on the calories, maybe try shifting your focus to understanding how she's *feeling*. Ask her why she wants to lose weight. What's driving that desire? What are her fears and insecurities around her body? Really listen to her, without judgment.

"Instead of pointing out what she's doing wrong, try focusing on what she's doing *right*. Celebrate small victories, like choosing a salad instead of something else. Offer to be a workout buddy, not a diet coach. Maybe suggest seeing a therapist together who specializes in body image issues or even just relationship communication. That could give you both a safe space to talk about these things without feeling attacked.

"Also, think about your own role in this. Are you being as supportive as you think you are? Are you truly listening to her feelings, or just waiting for your turn to offer advice? Sometimes, just being there and validating her feelings is the most helpful thing you can do. It is also possible that you are not 'hearing' her as well as you think you are.

"Ultimately, this is about her journey, not yours. You can offer support, but you can't force her to change. If she's not ready or willing to confront her issues, you need to respect that. Just keep communicating, being patient, and focusing on the love and connection you share. And maybe, just maybe, try to let go of the calorie counting for a while."
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview

[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy.
